Guide to eating vegan and gluten-free in Philadelphia
by Xxxxx Xxxxx, Xxxxx XX, 2019

Philadelphia, home of the cheesesteak, the soft pretzel, and America’s ice cream maker, may not seem like the most welcoming place to the dietary-restricted eater — people who must pass on pizza, go without grilled cheese, or abstain from asada. We feel your pain.

But Philly is actually a haven for this crowd — it’s also home to a heap of vegan cheesesteaks (enough to hold a contest), gluten-free cupcakes, and oat-milk options. Whatever flavor of dietary restriction you have, the city has options for you, and some are so compellingly delicious, your omnivorous friends will join you without being cajoled.

Allergy note: While the gluten-free label signifies restaurants with menu items that exclude ingredients containing gluten, we can’t guarantee that these restaurants entirely avoid cross-contamination from shared prep surfaces and airborne allergens. If you have a severe intolerance or allergy, please notify the restaurant before you order.

How to use our filters:

Select as many filters as you like to customize your list.

ADD FILTERS:

Northern Liberties/Fishtown
Blackbird Pizzeria
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
    • 613 n 2nd st. | 267-324-5224 | Restaurant website |$
    The 2014 Best Vegan Cheesesteak in Philly winner, from Blackbird Pizzeria. (COLIN KERRIGAN/Staff Photographer or staff, unsure)
    Go for

    A lively dinner among Philly’s vegan crowd

    The lowdown

    Blackbird Pizzeria, an all-vegan BYOB is a well-recognized staple for Philadelphia vegans. Its seitan cheesesteak won the Best Vegan Cheesesteak in Philly title in 2016 and 2017, and the spot also made the top 10 vegan wings in the U.S. in 2014. Their most popular pizza, the haymaker, comes with Violife cheese, oregano, red onions, and seitan sausage. Rather than using the ubiquitous Daiya cheese, owner Mark Mebus uses Violife brand, which he says is “the most meltable and convincing plant-based cheese” he has yet discovered. Mebus was part of the opening team for Horizons, alongside Philly vegan scene pioneers Rich Landau and Kate Jacoby.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    Front Street Cafe
  • Vegan
  • Gluten-free
  • Dairy-free
  • Carnivore-friendly
    • 1253 n front st. | 215-515-3073 | Restaurant website |$$
    The Front Street Benedict with tofu scramble over mushroom scrapple and hollandaise at the Front Street Café in Fishtown. The dish is vegan, and switching the English muffin for a gluten-free bagel can make it gluten-free as well. (MICHAEL BRYANT/Staff Photographer)
    Go for

    Boozy Sunday brunch

    The lowdown

    Just a block from the Girard stop on the El, you can’t miss Front Street Cafe, a sprawling, rustic-modern restaurant that’s a little bit of everything: coffee shop, bar, farm-to-table restaurant. In the warmer months, you can sit in the garden and sip a smoothie and some iced tea from the outdoor bar, and in the winter, come to the bar for beer, wine and fruit- and herb-inspired cocktails. They serve New American fare with an emphasis on vegetarian-, vegan- and allergy- friendly dishes like vegan waffle bites, their Front Street Benedict with tofu scramble and mushroom scrapple, and eggplant terrine. (They even have vegan, gluten-free mac and cheese with parmesan and mushroom “bacon.”)

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    SliCE
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
  • Carnivore-friendly
    • 431 e girard ave. | 215-425-1555 | Restaurant website |$
    The vegan meatless meat lover's pizza on a 10" crust at Slice Pizza, 431 E Girard Ave, photographed July 25, 2019. It's one of the food guide restaurants offering gluten free and dairy free food. (TOM GRALISH/Staff Photographer)
    Go for

    Late-night munchies

    The lowdown

    At this relaxed BYOB with counter service, don’t expect to be confined to the salads section (though they have some good options, like the kale and apple). They offer creative pizzas as well as calzones and strombolis. Unlike some pizza places, they don’t skimp on the Daiya cheese. Oh, and you can make your pizza heart-shaped on demand (but only if it isn’t gluten-free). Make sure to check the gluten status of toppings with the cashier or a manager before ordering. The gluten-free pizzas only come personal-pizza size (10 inches, 6 small slices).

    See Full Menu Jump to Top

    Spring Garden/Fairmount
    Goldie
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
    • whole foods market, 2101 pennsylvania ave. | no phone listed | Restaurant website |$
    Falafel from Goldie. (CRAIG LABAN/Staff)
    Go for

    Mid-afternoon snack or a quick, casual dinner.

    The lowdown

    Owned by Michael Solomonov and Steve Cook — the same team behind Zahav, Federal Donuts, and Abe Fisher — Goldie is 100 percent vegan and kosher and exceptionally accommodating of dietary restrictions. The menu is small but includes fluffy-crisp falafel served in pillowy pita bread (or over chopped salad), shawarma-spiced fries, and addictive dairy-free tehina milkshakes. Besides the eat-in space on Sansom Street, find Goldie at the Whole Foods’ food court on Pennsylvania Avenue as well as UPenn food hall Franklin’s Table.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top

    Center City/Rittenhouse
    Bao-logy
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
  • Carnivore-friendly
    • 1829 john f. kennedy blvd. | 215-999-2263 | Restaurant website |$$
    A vegetable dumpling at baology, 1829 JFK Blvd. (MICHAEL KLEIN/Staff)
    Go for

    BYOB egg-and-toastless brunch (on Saturday, it’s closed Sunday)

    The lowdown

    With iPad ordering and angular booths, this modern Taiwanese street food BYOB serves up a budget-friendly filling meal. As the name implies, Baology knows how to do gwa bao: the fluffy buns contain a variety of fillings, including King Oyster mushrooms (which won the 2019 StarChefs sustainability award). The ruen bing, a gluten-free wrap made of thin rice paper and filled with meat or bean curd, hoisin sauce and peanut powder, is also a specialty, as well as their tender dumplings and Forbidden Rice bento boxes. For lactose-intolerant diners, all items on their menu can be made dairy-free. Closed Sundays.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    Bar Bombon
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
    • 133 s. 18th st. | 267-606-6612 | Restaurant website |$$
    Bar Bombon, vegan Latin cuisine near Rittenhouse Square, tacos with blue tortillas, beans and rice Thursday, January 7, 2016. (STEVEN M. FALK/Staff Photographer)
    Go for

    After-work happy hour Mon- Fri 3-6 p.m.

    The lowdown

    Nicole Marquis' Puerto bustling corner bar-restaurant near Rittenhouse Square is only a few doors from her original eatery, the casual HipCityVeg. Bar Bombon is similarly plant-based, and the 3 p.m. happy hour start may inspire you to knock off early from work for drinks.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    Bareburger
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
  • Carnivore-friendly
    • 1109 walnut st. | 215-627-2273 | Restaurant website |$$
    The Duchess, featured on Bareburger's extensive vegan menu, is one of their most popular vegan dishes. It includes the famous Impossible burger patty, garlic aioli, caramelized onions, melty 'Gouda,' baby kale and a tomato slice on a vegan 'Vrioche' bun. (BAYLISS WAGNER/Staff)
    Go for

    An Impossible Burger

    The lowdown

    The Philly location of the international burger chain has one of the largest menus you’ll ever see (they claim it’s possible to create 81 million different burgers). Though Bareburger offers an array of meat options — bison and buttermilk-fried chicken, for example — vegans rave about its separate menu that features plant-based “eggs,” Beyond bratwurst, and five types of vegan burgers (including Impossible and Beyond Meat). A popular choice is the Duchess, an Impossible burger with garlic aioli, mushrooms, caramelized onions, baby kale and smoked vegan “gouda.” Bareburger’s emphasis on organic ingredients makes it a bit on the pricier side for burger joints.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    Barra Rossa
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
  • Carnivore-friendly
    • 929 walnut st. | 215-644-9074 | Restaurant website |$$
    The vegan hemp pasta pignoli is pictured at Barra Rossa in Center City Philadelphia on Thursday, Aug. 8, 2019. (TIM TAI/Staff Photographer)
    Go for

    Happy hour drink specials, or a late dinner

    The lowdown

    The upscale Italian restaurant and bar offers a vegan happy hour menu on Wednesday nights from 4 to 6 p.m, and a bustling atmosphere with friendly bartenders and servers to go along with it. Hit the half-price Monday-night pizza deal for the thin-crust vegan taco pizza (made with coconut-based Violife vegan cheese and Impossible “meat”). If you’re so inclined, try it gluten free, too.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    Charlie was a Sinner
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
    • 131 s 13th st. | 267-758-5372 | Restaurant website |$$
    Bucatini & Meatballs with chickpea ragout as served at Charlie was a sinner. (DAVID M WARREN/Staff Photographer)
    Go for

    A night out with friends.

    The lowdown

    Far from being a vegans-only enclave, this low-lit bar and restaurant from HipCityVeg and Bar Bombon owner Nicole Marquis those eager to taste creative cocktails like the spicy Road Less Traveled (single barrel bourbon, tangerine marmalade, amaro, Lillet Rouge and cherry bitters) and the East of Eden (with bourbon, tea-infused Dolin blanc, lillet and fig). Like the drinks, the food is strong on flavor in small plates like the tofu-based “ricotta” with crunchy sourdough, the spicy Korean fried tofu with pickled cauliflower, and the gluten-free Moroccan creamed spinach bakoula with salty olives. Come hungry.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    Fox & Son Fancy Corndogs
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
  • Carnivore-friendly
    • reading terminal market, 51 n 12th st | 215-372-7935 | Restaurant website |$
    The Classic funnel cake topped with strawberries and whipped cream at Fox & Son Fancy Corndogs, an entirely gluten-free stand in Reading Terminal Market. (MICHAEL CHANEY /Courtesy)
    Go for

    A rare indulgence in childhood memories

    The lowdown

    Fox & Sons Fancy Corndogs, a carnival-esque food stand that opened at Reading Terminal in Feb. 2017, struck a happy medium when they found a batter that happened to be gluten-free. The owners were inspired by the texture of Japanese and Chinese pastries, co-owner Rebecca Foxman says, which typically uses a blend of rice flour and corn starch. Their entirely gluten-free menu includes corn dogs, fried broccoli bites, fried cheese curds, funnel cake, and poutine (including a vegan option). The vegan funnel cake also saves food waste: they use ripe bananas that produce stands at Reading Terminal toss at the end of the day to replace the buttermilk and eggs in their traditional funnel cake recipe. The store also appeared on the Rachael Ray Show.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    Goldie
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
    • 1526 sansom st. | 267-239-0777 | Restaurant website |$
    A bag of falafel balls at Goldie, 1526 Sansom St. (MICHAEL KLEIN/Staff)
    Go for

    Mid-afternoon snack or a quick, casual dinner.

    The lowdown

    Owned by Michael Solomonov and Steve Cook — the same team behind Zahav, Federal Donuts, and Abe Fisher — Goldie is 100 percent vegan and kosher and exceptionally accommodating of dietary restrictions. The menu is small but includes fluffy-crisp falafel served in pillowy pita bread (or over chopped salad), shawarma-spiced fries, and addictive dairy-free tehina milkshakes. Besides the eat-in space on Sansom Street, find Goldie at the Whole Foods’ food court on Pennsylvania Avenue as well as UPenn food hall Franklin’s Table.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    HipCityVeg
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
    • 127 s 18th st. | 215-278-7605 | Restaurant website |$$
    Also at 121 s broad st. | 267-296-9001
    HipCityVeg's Smokey Sweet Chick'n Wrap — 100% vegan. (HIPCITYVEG/Hipcityveg)
    Go for

    A quick vegan bite

    The lowdown

    Philly vegan restaurateur Nicole Marquis opened the first fast-casual burger joint HipCityVeg in 2012. HipCityVeg serves up creamy vegan and lactose-free sauces: filling, crunchy salads with creamy caesar dressing, fried “chick’n” sandwiches with peppercorn ranch, garlic aioli, or chipotle crema, and curry tofu wraps with cumin raita. But the restaurant’s fast expansion, with four Philly locations, two locations in the Pa. suburbs and Washington, D.C., is a testament to its broad appeal.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    Luhv Vegan Deli
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
    • reading terminal market, 51 n 12th st. | 267-758-5779 | Restaurant website |$
    Tuna salad on Taffet's Bakery gluten-free bread at Luhv Vegan Deli in Reading Terminal. (BAYLISS WAGNER/Staff)
    Go for

    A quick, healthy lunch

    The lowdown

    Though Luhv Vegan Deli has only been open in Reading Terminal Market since 2018, the family behind it has been cooking for customers since 2016, when they began selling black bean and plantain burgers at local markets. Now available up and down the east coast (in markets from Connecticut to Virginia), the burger doesn’t crumble like other meatless burgers. At the deli, it comes with smoky vegan “gouda,” sauteed mushrooms and “mushroom mayo.” Another specialty is their gluten-free energy soup, a warming blend of beans, kale, quinoa, seaweed, and flax seed. The deli offers gluten-free sandwich bread, specially made to be vegan by local staple Taffet’s Bakery, for an extra $2. All of their burgers and soups are gluten-free, but the seitan, chicken salad, sausage, and all cold cuts contain gluten.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    P.S. & Co.
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
    • 1706 locust st. | 215-985-1706 | Restaurant website |$$
    The organic vegan and gluten free breakfast tacos are photographed at P.S. & Co. in Rittenhouse Square on Thursday, Aug. 08, 2019. (HEATHER KHALIFA/Staff Photographer)
    Go for

    Brunch

    The lowdown

    Rittenhouse hotspot P.S. and Co. is a good bet for those with dietary restrictions: the entire menu is plant-based and gluten-free. Andrea Kyan founded the restaurant after she went vegan in 2007, and found a lack of sweets to eat — so she started experimenting. The restaurant avoids what they call “unhealthful forms of soy and pea protein,” so they don’t make or sell any processed meat substitutes. The space is airy and photogenic but not the best bet for large groups — it’s a better bet for a few friends. It’s packed for brunch on weekends, so reservations are a plus.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    Strangelove's
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Carnivore-friendly
    • 216 s 11th st. | 215-873-0404 | Restaurant website |$$
    The vegetarian huevos rancheros, which can be made vegan, at Strangelove's. (STRANGELOVE'S/Strangelove's)
    Go for

    Quizzo at 9pm on Monday nights, or weekend brunch.

    The lowdown

    With weekly events like quizzo Strangelove’s has the feel of a quirky neighborhood bar. They serve pub-style food, like fried calamari and burgers, with more vegan options than your typical beer joint. Try the $15 weekday two-course lunch special with fried Brussels sprouts or the vegetarian nachos with Daiya cheese or the Craig LaBan-approved Russian kale salad, or vegan veggie burger. There’s also a weekend brunch with plenty of allergy- and vegan- friendly options.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    V Street
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
    • 126 south 19th st. | 215-278-7943 | Restaurant website |$$
    Fried Korean tempeh tacos, with gochujang chile paste and radish kimchi, served in soft tortillas. The V Street restaurant's nutty tempeh and flavorful tofu prove chef-owner Rich Landau's mastery of meat-replacement. (2015) (TOM GRALISH/Staff Photographer)
    Go for

    Boozy Saturday lunch date

    The lowdown

    You won’t see ‘tempeh sausage’ or ‘soy-based chicken’ on the menu at vegan bar/restaurant V Street. James Beard-nominated chefs Rich Landau and Kate Jacoby opened the place in 2014 as a lower-cost (but still pricey) offshoot of the wildly successful Vedge. They took inspiration from street foods around the world to create a menu that touches Southeast Asias, South American, Caribbean and African subcontinental flavors. V Street offers soy-free and gluten-free menus to guests with dietary restrictions. They also can modify their menu to accommodate other allergies if you call in advance.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top

    Washington Square/South Street
    Giorgio on Pine
  • Gluten-free
  • Carnivore-friendly
    • 1328 pine st. | 215-545-6265 | Restaurant website |$$$
    The Fusilli Primavera is photographed at Giorgio On Pine in Center City, Philadelphia on Thursday, Aug. 08, 2019. (HEATHER KHALIFA/Staff Photographer)
    Go for

    A filling Italian meal with a group

    The lowdown

    This cozy BYOB, at the corner of Pine and S. Juniper Streets, lets you eat Italian but skip the gluten. The restaurant offers both a regular menu and a menu with gluten-free substitutions, so there’s a variety of appetizers, pizzas and pasta dishes that suit everyone’s needs. Along with the pizza and pasta, they offer gluten-free classics like mussels, calamari, a prosciutto platter, ribeye with mushroom sauce and veal prosciutto. Even the breadcrumbs in the kale salad and the Parmesan-crusted chicken breast are gluten-free. There are homemade desserts as well, like their flourless chocolate cake, cannoli, and creme bruleé. Make sure to book a reservation before you go.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    Tattooed Mom
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
    • 530 south st. | 215-238-9880 | Restaurant website |$$
    A vegan cajun blackened "chicken" burger from Tattooed Mom in South Philly. (ELIJAH SNYDER-VIDMAR/Tattooed Mom)
    Go for

    A playful and affordable night out, Meatless Mondays

    The lowdown

    A South Street staple since 1997, Tattooed Mom’s kitchen turns out bar food for vegans and for carnivores alike, making it the perfect hangout for eaters of all stripes. The vegan menu is thanks, in part, to how staff members’ own diets have evolved. It has plenty of bar food that people with dietary restrictions can enjoy — complete with specials like Meatless Mondays (half off the full plant-based menu) and taco Tuesdays. It also boasts a daily late night happy hour from 10-11 p.m., perfect for a late night snack and drink.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    Vedge
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
    • 1221 locust st. | 215-320-7500 | Restaurant website |$$$
    Sour cherry cheesecake with cola gel and potato chip ice cream at Vedge. (VEDGE/Vedge)
    Go for

    Dinner on a special occasion with foodie friends

    The lowdown

    Awarded the elusive four bells by Craig LaBan, the all-vegan bar and restaurant Vedge is a national landmark of vegan cuisine. “More than enough carnivore minds have been blown” by its seasonally rotating menu, which features small plates with intense flavors that are ordered to share as well as creative drinks. It’s a fine dining experience, as you enjoy your multiple courses and dessert in the spacious, modern dining room, but don’t expect to find seats unless you book at least a week in advance. Vedge offers separate soy- and gluten-free menus and can accommodate other allergies if diners call ahead.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    Zavino
  • Gluten-free
  • Carnivore-friendly
    • 112 s 13th st. | 215-732-2400 | Restaurant website |$$
    The vegetarian spaghetti squash, which can be made vegan without cheese, is pictured at Zavino in Philadelphia's University City section on Thursday, Aug. 8, 2019. (TIM TAI/Staff Photographer)
    Go for

    A slightly-fancier version of a pizza + beer night out.

    The lowdown

    Zavino, while known for its pizza, is not a regular pizza joint. The white marble tables, fully-stocked bar and antipasti station signal that while they serve reasonably priced pies, they also cater to those who would seek out the pricier tasting board. At the University City location, you can watch a chef spin the gluten-free crust behind the bar (fluffy but crunchy and baked in a wood-fired oven). They don’t carry vegan cheese, but their pizzas can be made vegan and/or dairy free. (They can make other items dairy-free.) Their gluten-free crusts, however, contain milk.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top

    South Philly
    Grindcore House
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
    • 1515 s 4th st. | 215-839-3333 | Restaurant website |$
    A gluten-free, vegan cheesecake brownie at Grindcore House on Sun., July 21. (BAYLISS WAGNER/Staff)
    Go for

    Coffee with a side of communist literature

    The lowdown

    Grindcore House is the most hardcore all-vegan cafe you’ll find in Philadelphia. Heavy metal music greets visitors who step into the store, which has a glass case full of vegan treats — including the popular Dottie’s Donuts. Deeper in the cafe’s space is an extensive library of radical literature. Their menu features many bagels, sandwiches and salads, like the popular kropotkin, which includes field roast, pesto, mixed greens, roasted red peppers, onion, and vegan mayonnaise on ciabatta, as well as their vegan cream cheeses, including olive, jalapeño and scallion.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    SliCE
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
  • Carnivore-friendly
    • 1180 south 10th st. | 215-463-0868 | Restaurant website |$
    The vegan meatless meat lover's pizza on a 10" gluten-free crust (toppings not gluten free) at Slice Pizza. Though the Daiya mozzarella on the pizza is not as stringy as real cheese, it is gooey and rich. (TOM GRALISH/Staff Photographer)
    Go for

    Late-night munchies

    The lowdown

    At this relaxed BYOB with counter service, don’t expect to be confined to the salads section (though they have some good options, like the kale and apple). They offer creative pizzas as well as calzones and strombolis. Unlike some pizza places, they don’t skimp on the Daiya cheese. Oh, and you can make your pizza heart-shaped on demand (but only if it isn’t gluten-free). Make sure to check the gluten status of toppings with the cashier or a manager before ordering. The gluten-free pizzas only come personal-pizza size (10 inches, 6 small slices).

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    Sweet Freedom Bakery
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
    • 1424 south st. | 215-545-1899 | Restaurant website |$
    Tiramisu cupcake, a special that day, at Sweet Freedom Bakery in South Philly on July 27. (BAYLISS WAGNER/Staff)
    Go for

    A major sweet fix

    The lowdown

    Sweet Freedom brands itself as Philadelphia’s first all-around dietary-restriction-friendly bakery. The bakery is vegan, gluten-free, soy free, nut free, kosher, and refined-sugar free. And, somehow, this quiet South Street joint manages to make you forget what’s not in the food. Sweet Freedom replaces dairy, animal, and gluten products with a variety of ingredients, many of them coconut products, — oil, milk, and sugar — as well as sorghum flour, potato starch and rice flour. Sweet Freedom was featured on the Food Network’s Cupcake Wars, and earned stellar reviews for some of their clever creations. The bakery takes orders by phone, and both ships and delivers.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    The Tasty
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
    • 1401 s. 12th st. | 267-457-5670 | Restaurant website |$$
    Chick'n and Waffles at The Tasty, a South Philly vegan diner, on Sun., July 21. (BAYLISS WAGNER/Staff)
    Go for

    Breakfast or lunch with a no-frills, classic diner vibe

    The lowdown

    Co-owner Sofia Baltopoulos and her business partner opened The Tasty three years ago, after noticing that none of the area’s diners had more than one or two vegan options. The Tasty is 100% vegan, and also offers an additional gluten-free menu. The South Philly spot has custom coffee drinks, colorful doughnuts and pastries and a classic diner vibe of swivel bar chairs and homey booths. They serve all the classics, veganized: cheesy omelets and scrambles, Tex-Mex breakfast burritos, pancakes, French toast, and waffles,which stand up to regular diner food.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top

    West Philly
    Dim Sum House by Jane G's
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
  • Carnivore-friendly
    • 3939 chestnut st. | 215-921-5377 | Restaurant website |$$
    Hot and sour soup from Dim Sum House. (KOREY AVERSA/Staff Photographer)
    Go for

    A late-night group hangout

    The lowdown

    Opened by the owners of the popular Jane G’s Authentic Sichuan, Dim Sum House by Jane G’s opened in 2016. The restaurant has a laid-back, but sleek, design, with old Shanghai-inspired decor, a pool table, a full bar, two dining rooms and a private dining space. Almost everything here is dairy-free, plenty is gluten-free, and there are many unique Cantonese- and Shanghai-inspired dim sum dishes that are vegan. They have happy hour from 5-7 p.m. daily, and are open 1 a.m. every day except Monday.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    Goldie
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
    • franklin's table, 3401 walnut st. | 215-557-0015 | Restaurant website |$
    A bag of falafel balls at Goldie, 1526 Sansom St. (MICHAEL KLEIN/Staff)
    Go for

    Mid-afternoon snack or a quick, casual dinner.

    The lowdown

    Owned by Michael Solomonov and Steve Cook — the same team behind Zahav, Federal Donuts, and Abe Fisher — Goldie is 100 percent vegan and kosher and exceptionally accommodating of dietary restrictions. Besides the eat-in space on Sansom Street, find Goldie at the Whole Foods’ food court on Pennsylvania Avenue as well as UPenn food hall Franklin’s Table.

    HipCityVeg
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
    • 214 s 40th st. | 267-244-4342 | Restaurant website |$$
    The Buffalo Bella sandwich with sweet potato fries at HipCityVeg in Center City. (RON TARVER/Staff Photographer)
    Go for

    A quick vegan bite

    The lowdown

    Philly vegan restaurateur Nicole Marquis opened the first fast-casual burger joint HipCityVeg in 2012. HipCityVeg serves up creamy vegan and lactose-free sauces: filling, crunchy salads with creamy caesar dressing, fried “chick’n” sandwiches with peppercorn ranch, garlic aioli, or chipotle crema, and curry tofu wraps with cumin raita. But the restaurant’s fast expansion, with four Philly locations, two locations in the Pa. suburbs and Washington, D.C., is a testament to its broad appeal.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    White Dog Cafe
  • Vegan
  • Dairy-free
  • Gluten-free
  • Carnivore-friendly
    • 3420 sansom st. | 215-386-9224 | Restaurant website |$$$
    Go for

    Martinis, celebratory brunch

    The lowdown

    White Dog Cafe is more than just a kitschy, canine-themed bistro. This upscale standby, which has been around for nearly four decades and has multiple suburban locations, expanded to become one of the largest restaurants in UCity. The 12-seat parlor bar and an elegant staircase leading to the second level complement the plush booths and lush greenery that fill the restaurant. White Dog offers vegetarian and vegan menus upon request.

    See Full Menu Jump to Top
    Zavino
  • Gluten-free
  • Carnivore-friendly
    • 3200 chestnut st. | 215-823-6897 | Restaurant website |$$
    The stache pizza with gluten-free crust is pictured at Zavino in Philadelphia's University City section on Thursday, Aug. 8, 2019. (TIM TAI/Staff Photographer)
    Go for

    A slightly-fancier version of a pizza + beer night out.

    The lowdown

    Zavino, while known for its pizza, is not a regular pizza joint. The white marble tables, fully-stocked bar and antipasti station signal that while they serve reasonably priced pies, they also cater to those who would seek out the pricier tasting board. At the University City location, you can watch a chef spin the gluten-free crust behind the bar (fluffy but crunchy and baked in a wood-fired oven). They don’t carry vegan cheese, but their pizzas can be made vegan and/or dairy free. (They can make other items dairy-free.) Their gluten-free crusts, however, contain milk.
